docs.lead_paragraph: Adam Clymer, former chief Washington correspondent of The New York Times and author of "Edward M. Kennedy: A Biography," answered selected questions from readers about Senator Kennedy's life and legacy. No additional questions or comments are being accepted.

headline.main: Q. and A. About Senator Kennedy

docs.abstract: Adam Clymer, former chief Washington correspondent of The New York Times and author of "Edward M. Kennedy: A Biography," is answering questions from readers about Senator Kennedy's life and legacy.
docs.snippet: Adam Clymer, former chief Washington correspondent of The New York Times and author of "Edward M. Kennedy: A Biography," is answering questions from readers about Senator Kennedy's life and legacy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Opponents of a health care overhaul have been stoking fears that a government health plan would entail "death panels" that deny treatment to sick people. Now, a liberal group financed by two large labor unions is turning the tables with an attack ad that portrays health insurance companies denying medical care to patients as the "real death panels in America."

headline.main: Ad Watch: Union-Sponsored Group Casts Insurers as 'Death Panels'

docs.abstract: An advocacy group financed by labor unions takes aim at the insurance industry.
docs.snippet: An advocacy group financed by labor unions takes aim at the insurance industry.

docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine you are a lawyer working at the administrative offices of the Community Health Law Project at 185 Valley Street in South Orange. The project is a public interest advocacy organization with client offices around the state helping people who are disabled because of physical or mental disabilities, HIV/AIDS, developmental disabilities and visual impairments.

headline.main: Legal Life: Stay Here, In the Public Interest

docs.abstract: While in Beijing in November, I hope our President and his wife, two lawyers, will speak out on the problems that public interest lawyers in China have trying to advance civil rights and the rule of law.

headline.seo: Readers React to Edward Kennedy's Death
headline.main: Readers React to Edward Kennedy's Death

docs.snippet: Readers react to the death of Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts leaves a rich legislative legacy on a wide range of issues, including civil rights, health care, education, voting rights and labor.
docs.abstract: Sen. Edward M. Kennedy leaves a long legislative legacy that extends even to corporate bankruptcy: His amendment to a 2005 law sought to stop big bonuses for executives at companies in Chapter 11.
docs.snippet: Sen. Edward M. Kennedy leaves a long legislative legacy that extends even to corporate bankruptcy: His amendment to a 2005 law sought to stop big bonuses for executives at companies in Chapter 11.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the brother of John and Robert Kennedy who came to be known as the lion of the Senate in his own right, died of brain cancer at age 77 on Tuesday.

headline.main: Edward M. Kennedy Dies at 77: Official Statements

docs.abstract: "We've lost the irreplaceable center of our family and joyous light in our lives, but the inspiration of his faith, optimism, and perseverance will live on in our hearts forever," Mr. Kennedy's family said.
docs.snippet: "We've lost the irreplaceable center of our family and joyous light in our lives, but the inspiration of his faith, optimism, and perseverance will live on in our hearts forever," Mr. Kennedy's family said.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama announced on Tuesday that he would nominate Ben S. Bernanke to a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve. He praised Mr. Bernanke as being calm and bold in combating the financial crisis. Many others have credited the Fed for reacting swiftly to frozen credit markets and forestalling even greater financial calamity. He has, however, been strongly criticized for downplaying concerns about the subprime bubble as late as 2007, and for letting Lehman Brothers fail last fall.
docs.abstract: What the Fed chairman should do as the economy inches toward recovery.
docs.snippet: What the Fed chairman should do as the economy inches toward recovery.
